text: <@U13TWBRBL> my goal is prototype development and learning curve
I guess I should check out the most exciting stuff - v1.0
<@U1CTBUNEN> :+1: yes I guaranteed you trying v1.0 stuff will be very exciting :smiling_imp:

<@U13TWBRBL> Is it a bad idea to be working with dated (albeit public) versions to learn how to set up and use IBM Blockchain?  In particular, HFC 0.5.3 (using RPC instead of REST) in samples (like IBM-Blockchain/SDK-Demo) on the current IBM Blockchain Beta network?
I’m investigating it with a couple folks on my team.  The REST based demos work great, but as we step outside the box and use HFC 0.5.3, we see some issues
Don’t want to go down a rat hole if its a waste of time.
<@U2RCN8W95> i would suggest going with fabric 0.6 and hfc 0.6.x (latest) if you have an immediate/short-term goal of getting something running
We haven’t run the fabric anywhere but on the Bluemix Beta, so we’ll head down the path of setting it up to run local.

if you want to get familiar with the new architecture (because a lot have changed in how to deploy and how to program) as a long-term goal, then v1.0 stuff is working just enough for you to play around with
yep v0.6 is local only (using docker, or build from source if you want)
Do we need to get access to the gerrit repo to get the latest though?
bluemix team is working on upgrading to v0.6
you can get latest from <http://github.com/hyperledger|github.com/hyperledger>
How soon will Bluemix be on 0.6?
you can ask Mihir on an IBM channel since that’s internal info :wink:
Mihir Shah
Thanks!
yw
<@U2XLB7CFR|dc> has joined the channel
<@U2X9KDDL7|vdods> has joined the channel
<@U2W9UF8T1|dingsor> has joined the channel

I've got a question clarifying some concepts here: Say I want to initialize a node.js server -- what are the correct steps to do so?  1) create a new chain via hfc.newChain, 2) set an orderer URL via chain.setOrderer, 3) set a memberservices URL via chain.setMemberServicesUrl, 4) enroll the admin user via chain.enroll, 5) here is where I'm unclear -- do I have to send a deployment proposal, or an endorsement proposal?  What if I'm in chaincodedev mode, and the chaincode is already running?

and finally, assuming that the server has correctly connected to and initialized the services, how does one invoke/query?  I no longer see those methods anywhere in hfc.  Presumably this is done via Member.sendTransaction, but the documentation doesn't describe the form of its parameters
<@U2X9KDDL7> - I’ve been using this as a sample: <https://github.com/IBM-Blockchain/SDK-Demo/blob/master/helloblockchain.js>

attachments.title: IBM-Blockchain/SDK-Demo
attachments.text: SDK-Demo - Sample Node.js program to demonstrate the HFC SDK APIs interacting with Starter and High Security Bluemix networks

text: <@U2RCN8W95> That'd be perfect although I believe that is hfc@0.5.x, and I'm using 0.6.x.  Maybe I should downgrade though for now.
<@U2RCN8W95> What versions of various things are you using?  I'd guess fabric 0.5 and hfc 0.5?

The docs I’ve found suggest using HFC 0.5.3 and I was running it against the Bluemix Beta, but … there are some inconsistencies.  I noted that earlier.  So, I’m now setting up a network peer to run locally (latest hyperledger) in hopes to run that same sample against it, maybe with an updated HFC, and see if that works.
Sorry, you're not setting up a network peer to run locally, or you're now setting up?

<@U2X9KDDL7> i haven’t played with a network in dev mode using the latest SDK, but i don’t believe it’ll work because we haven’t done the coding to support deploying chaincode to target network in dev mode (yet it still requires deploying the chaincode)
so you need to call sendDeploymentProposal() first, then sendTransaction() using end-to-end.js as an example for how to get the values from ProposalResponse into the transaction object
this gets your chaincode deployed
and that’s the extent it’ll work as of now
<@U1KFBBWG1> is working on changeset that does the transaction invocation proposal to support the next step (calling transactions)
<@U2X9KDDL7> Sorry, I meant “now”.  Will edit that last message
<@U13TWBRBL> where can I find the v1.0 branch? I see master and v0.6 on github ?
“master” is it
<@U2RCN8W95> What git repo/branch (or docker images?) are you using to run fabric 0.5 and hfc 0.5?  I may try downgrading until the latest HFC work that jzhang mentioned is done.

<@U2X9KDDL7> I’m still setting up and trying to sort it out right now.  I’ll report here if I get a combination working.  I’m starting with instructions here: <https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/blob/master/docs/dev-setup/devenv.md>
<@U2X9KDDL7> if you are setting up fabric locally/yourself instead of relying on bluemix service, you should definitely stay on v0.6 for both fabric and hfc
there are numerous fixes in there compared to v0.5.x plus some significant API changes
<@U2RCN8W95> <@U13TWBRBL> Noted, thanks!
That’s also a reminder that the sample code using HFC in the <http://github.com/IBM-Blockchain/SDK-Demo|github.com/IBM-Blockchain/SDK-Demo> won’t be compatible - some interface changes will be needed
Right -- I had encountered that a while ago, which prompted me to try 0.6

Running <https://github.com/IBM-Blockchain/SDK-Demo> with hfc::

having this error

`Error:  Failed to register and enroll JohnDoe: Error: Invalid affiliation group  at Error (native)`
